reviewText: I was excited to get this DVD set as a Vine choice as I nearly have purchased this set for my wife on a few occasions. We both like the mysteries one sees on PBS/BBC. I also couldn't stand the main character as she is completely unbelievable for the time period. It's just not feasible that someone would have a personality that belongs in the 1990s or later in the Roaring Twenties. She feels far too much like a time traveler than knows she's out of sorts than an actual character from the era in question. Add in the fact that the mysteries were pretty paint by numbers and the killer was obvious and  you have to wonder if Vince Russo was writing the series rather than one Kerry Greenwood.So yes, I disliked the series royally, but my wife had fun with it. It's not a keeper and if it wasn't for her liking it, this would be getting a 1-2 star review from me. Still, the difference of opinion lets me know that this is probably for someone out there; just not me.

reviewText: While the Mrs. Bradley Mysteries (only the one episode I found) was very good and Diana Rigg exceptional, for some reason, the Brits chose not to extend her sleuthiness. reviewText: Move over, Mrs Bradley - there's another jazz-age lady sleuth in town! Author Kerry Greenwood first began writing her series of "Phryne Fisher" books in 1989, and earned legions of fans worldwide with her glamorous, sharp-witted 1920's heroine, Miss Phryne Fisher.The Hon. Phryne Fisher has returned to Melbourne, Australia after many years of living abroad.  Despite her well-heeled manner, Phryne hides a hardscrabble childhood spent in abject poverty, and is still haunted by the mysterious disappearance of her beloved sister Janey.  It takes only a few moments after Phryne's arrival on the Melbourne dock for the murders and mysteries to start, but with her talent for attracting friends from all walks of life, including cab drivers Bert (Travis McMahon) and Cec (Anthony Sharpe), Mr Butler (Richard Bligh), Constable Hugh Collins (Hugo Johnstone-Burt), Aunt Prudence (Miriam Margolyes), Dr Mac (Tammy Macintosh) and new ward Jane (Ruby Rees Wemyss), Phryne is ready for anything!Phryne's delicious "will they-won't they" banter with Detective Jack Robinson (Nathan Page) drives a great deal of the tension within the series.  The early episodes rattle along gloriously and are hugely enjoyable as "single" adventures, however things take a darker tone starting in the 11th episode, "Blood and Circuses", as Phryne's quest to finally avenge her sister's needless death at the hands of criminal Murdoch Foyle (Nicholas Bell in a chilling performance) comes to a thrilling climax.  The final three episodes careen along at breakneck speed, taking Phryne, her family and friends through their most terrifying and deadly brushes with Foyle.Essie Davis plays the resourceful Miss Fisher and it is indeed a sensational performance.  One of Australia's finest, Ms Davis beautifully covers all the facets of Phryne with style and boundless energy.  And that's not a wig - the quick turnaround on the filming of this series required Davis to dye and blunt-cut her own hair into Miss Fisher's sleek signature black bob.Episodes:"Cocaine Blues" - Fresh off the ship from London, Miss Phryne Fisher's Melbourne homecoming will have to take a backseat when she is asked to unravel the bizarre link between a chain of murders and a continental bath, which Phryne soon discovers disguises an opium syndicate and an illegal abortion ring.  Guest stars Maria Mercedes, Kristof Piechocki and Miranda Otto."Murder on the Ballarat Train" - Phryne and new companion Dot Collins (Ashleigh Cummings) board the train to Ballarat in order to collect her new Hispano-Suiza sports car, but when the train makes a short overnight water-stop at Bacchus Marsh, a corpse is later discovered dangling from the water tower.  Guest stars Maeve Dermody, Jacek Koman, Victoria Eagger, Abbe Holmes and David Berry."The Green Mill Murder" - Phryne must untangle a web of blackmail encircling old family friends when a dead body shows up on the dancefloor of Melbourne's most decadent new speakeasy, the Green Mill.  Guest stars Deni Hines, Arthur Angel, Wendy Hughes, Lauren Clair, Rohan Nicol and Toby Schmitz."Death at Victoria Dock" - Whilst she investigates the disappearance of the daughter of an automobile factory owner, Phryne also becomes caught up in the world of the Latvian anarchists who are striking on Victoria Dock.  Guest stars Robert Grubb, Penne Hackforth-Jones, Karlis Zaid and Vladimir Tsyganov."Raisins and Almonds" - When the owner of a bookshop in Melbourne's Jewish community suddenly drops dead, Phryne is led into a fascinating case involving old family wounds and the formula for synthetic rubber.  Guest stars Tim Draxl, Kat Stewart, Adam Schmerl, Brian Lipson and Adrian Mulraney."Ruddy Gore" - A vengeful theatre ghost doesn't have much of an appreciation for Gilbert & Sullivan, as Phryne soon discovers in one of her most bizarre cases, which also leads her to her first encounter with Lin Chung (Phillipe Sung).  Guest stars Peter Cousens, Christie Whelan, Alex Rathgeber, Debra Lawrance and Bille Brown."Murder in Montparnasse" - Phryne's post-war occupation as an artist's model in Paris comes back into the spotlight when Veronique Sarcelle (Linda Cropper), the widow of the artist who considered Phryne to be his greatest muse, travels to Melbourne and asks Phryne to help solve his puzzling death.  Guest stars Vince Colosimo, Peter O'Brien, Nick Carrafa, Renaud Jadin and Ben Prendergast."Away With the Fairies" - Phryne is called in to investigate the death of a magazine author, beloved by her fans but despised by her co-workers, of whom any could have easily murdered her.  Guest stars Deborah Kennedy, Anna McGahan, Roz Hammond and Amanda Ma."Queen of the Flowers" - When Phryne is invited to act as the hostess for an annual presentation day for disadvantaged girls, the festive mood is soon blotted by a series of unexpected murders among the contestants. Guest stars Danielle Cormack, Terry Norris, Taylor Ferguson, Andrew S. Gilbert and Eva Lazzaro."Death By Miss Adventure" - A series of seemingly accidental deaths at a Melbourne textile factory leads to Dr Mac being questioned as a possible murderer - and danger for Dot when she goes undercover as the new tea-lady... reviewText: This series is set in Australia in the 1920's.  Its star is Phyrne (pronounce fry-knee with emphasis on the first syllable).  She's an example of a new woman who's independently wealthy or at least comfortable, intelligent, inquisitive and resourceful.  She quickly gathers around her two streetwise drivers and a ladies maid and butler, all of whom also double as fellow investigators.  The series touches on many issues of the day.  I especially liked all the references to World War I and its emotional and practical impact on Phyrne and society at large.  The cast features a blend of excellent Aussie and Brit actors.  Miss Fisher, Essie Davis and Ashleigh Cummings, her ladies maid, are almost ethereally beautiful.  Davis's skin is positively luminescent and the director doesn't miss a chance to show as much of it as he can.  I'm not sure how much of the effect is due to lighting genius but there are some lovely shots.  Which leads me to another aspect of this series.  There are plenty of pre and post love making scenes so you might want to keep this in mind of you have younger children.The `almost' love interest and working relationship between Phyrne and the local chief of police is entertaining.  Nathan Page is VERY handsome in an offbeat but extremely masculine way and the chemistry between Davis and Page is electric.  Topics the series touches on are labor relations, the loss of loved ones particularly in the war, drug and alcohol abuse, the political climate throughout the world and it's affect on individuals, the outrageous wealth of some individuals at this time, Egypt and it's lore.  The last two episodes are especially great and are really one extended story line.  I enjoyed this series a lot.  If you like Miss Marple mysteries with some near explicit love scenes and a sharper edge you'll enjoy this series too.  Only Miss Fisher's name is conventional.

reviewText: When I think of the "roaring '20s," I think of "Thoroughly Modern Millie" and other fun romps, with a wide-eyed young flapper sipping bathtub gin and leading a selection of besotted beaus around by the nose. Certainly, Phryne (pronounced FRY-nee) Fisher has some of those characteristics, though she's a mature woman rather than a sweet young thing. Phryne, played by Essie Davis, looks the part of a flapper, with her revealing frocks and sleek helmet of black hair that's rarely mussed even in the throes of chasing a bad guy or bedding a rather better one. What appears to be a budding romance with Detective Inspector Jack Robinson of the Melbourne, Australia, police force has just enough spice to make it interesting. Phryne isn't afraid to take risks, from climbing in a second-story window to snoop for clues to flying a biplane to find a suspect's missing brother. She also carries a pistol in her purse, and she isn't afraid to use it.But beneath Phryne's devil-may-care exterior is a woman with hidden wounds, chief among them what happened to her sister years ago. While we can forget that for a time as she goes from one madcap adventure to the next, it's always there. And it surfaces in a big way in the last few episodes of this 13-episode set.Phryne uses her charm to rope in a variety of helpers, from a couple of cabbies to her strait-laced young maid Dot, who initially has to overcome her fear of using the telephone. There's usually an undercurrent of humor or irony in these episodes, but it doesn't detract from more serious events. And lest the viewer forget, it takes place only a few years after the end of "the war to end all wars," which left so many devastated, physically and/or psychologically. That plays a part in some of the episodes.This is a fun series with a serious side that kept my attention. I also enjoyed seeing Phryne's endless supply of delectable frocks and headpieces, as well as the vintage autos. Those who like British murder mysteries such as Miss Marple and Inspector Poirot should enjoy this series.
summary: A roaring '20s romp with a serious side

reviewText: The Honorable Phryne Fisher has a lot in common with Emma Peel. Smart, dresses to kill, athletic, sexy and courageous. And they both solve mysteries. Except Phryne (pronounced FRY-knee) lives in 1928 and her foes are more realistic than the I-vant-to-rule-the-world type usually found in "The Avengers".We first meet Phryne disembarking at Melbourne, Australia. She almost immediately receives an engraved invitation to dine with her old friends, Lydia and John Andrews, and her indefatigable gossip of an aunt.When Phryne arrives at the Andrews', it's just in time to see her host's body carried out on a police stretcher. According to Aunt Prudence, "It seems that John collapsed suddenly after a light breakfast of tea and kumquat marmalade toast. And the maid found him, purple in the face and cold to the touch on the bathroom floor."Phryne's investigation leads her to several interesting characters, including a French-Russian tango dancer, a Turkish bath owner and a handsome police detective. The last because, yes, John Andrews was murdered - with poison in the sugar bowl.But what's especially interesting is when we get the first inkling of why Phryne really came to Melbourne. She visits a man in jail. We aren't given much information in the beginning, except we know it has to do with her late sister Janey. Phryne tells him, "I've come half way around the world to make sure that you never get out of here alive..... Whatever horrors you visited on her [Jane], I have imagined tenfold, and given the chance, I will do the same to you without smearing my lipstick."This Australian Broadcasting Corporation series is based on the mysteries written by Kerry Greenwood. I haven't read the books, so I had no preconceptions. Until about 10 minutes into the 1st episode of "Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries", I thought that this series might be a little light and mannered for it to really impress me. But as we see more of Phryne and those who become her cohorts, this becomes a series with more substance and layers. There's a lot of humor, too, and I ended up really liking the series. Instead of me rambling on, read some of the comments I gleaned from different people in the DVD set's extras, see below.In this set, you get 4 discs with 13 episodes, a total of 706 minutes of great viewing.DVD extras on Disc 4:1.  "The Look" (19 minutes) How they come up with the costumes, characters, sets and locations for 1928 Melbourne, including lots of rehearsal and set-up clips. Commentators are Scooter Welbourn (3rd assistant director), Roger Lanser (director of photography), Marion Boyce (costume designer), Tony Tilse (start up director), Scott Zero (visual effects designer), Kerry Greenwood (author of originating books), Robert Perkins (production designer) and Anna Karpinski (hair & makeup designer).Boyce mentions that there were "at least 150 outfits for Essia" (Essia Davis, who plays Phryne).With Zero, there are some great clips of scene creation, such as when a character falls off a roof or when three men have a fight with an ax - as they couldn't have an actor actually swinging an ax in actual fighting range.2.  "Meet the Creators" (5 minutes) Commentators are Kerry Greenwood, Fiona Eagger (producer) and Deb Cox (producer 7 series screenwriter). Kerry had input on key character casting, and was impressed with Essia. "I just saw her walking into a room, and she's got the understated arrogance that Phryne has to have. Phryne's a female hero. She isn't an ordinary mortal." And I'll add my two cents. I really liked that Phryne (though beautiful) is not some young thing. For Phryne to have experiences and depth, it would not have worked to have an actress too young. Phryne nursed in the war and can fly a plane, throw a dagger, climb a mountain, shoot a gun - and speak Mandarin. Above all she is a quiet observer when she needs to be, her big eyes intelligently taking it all in, her deep voice calming or cutting as required. Phryne's a little larger than life, but we expect that in an athletic protagonist.Deb Cox says, "I wasn't interested in doing something orthodox. I wasn't interested in replicating the Miss Marples and the Poirots."3.  "Set Tour" (4 minutes) Kerry Greenwood takes us through the sets for two rooms in Phryne's house, explaining how perfectly production got the period details. Even the books on the bookshelf are real and correctly contemporary.4.  "Cast Interviews" (8 minutes) Commentators are Essie Davis, Nathan Page (plays Detective Inspector Jack Robinson, with a most deep and melodious voice), Ashleigh Cummings (plays Dorothy "Dot" Williams), and Hugo Johnston-Burt (plays Constable Hugh Collins).Davis says of Phryne, "She's extremely wealthy, but has come from great poverty, so she understands an enormous cross-section of humanity." And, as you find out right away in episode 1, Phryne is a "hedonistic lady"!5.  "Vehicles of the Series" (3 minutes) Only one vehicle is covered, but it's a beaut. Phryne's red Hispano-Suiza. Bob, the gentleman who restored and owns the car, calls it the "supercar of the 1920's".6.  "Steam Train Experts" (2 minutes) Jim Murty and Steve Lumsden, the volunteer steam train driver and fireman talk about the train and its operation.7.  "Locations in Melbourne" (5 minutes) Clips of shooting and/or rehearsals are shown for 15 different locations used during the series.8.  Photo Gallery (2 minutes) Publicity stills and production stills.9.  PDF "St. Kilda Tribune" Put the DVD in your computer and you bring up the (fake) front page of the May 13, 1928 St. Kilda Tribune. The lead headline is "Murder Most Stylish - The Wonderful Miss Fisher Solves Yet Another Murder".

reviewText: I've read many of the Phryne Fisher books, and of course, Phryne is a total Mary Sue character; she's beautiful, alluring, irresistible, rich, smart, compelling, can fly planes, drive fast, wears Erte gowns... the whole schmear.  When your brain needs a little brain-candy, something along the lines of a cozy, but not quite Miss Marple, the Phryne Fishers are fine, as long as you don't expect too much from them.  The TV series, though, isn't quite up to the snuff of the books, and the fault for most of that really has to fall on the shoulders of the series' star, Essie Davis, who "coyly" refuses to list her age but is shown quite clearly in various online sources to be 43.  And that's part of the problem.While Phryne is no infant in the books, she's not 43, either.  She was patently 28 in one of the early novels, and she's not supposed to be nearly 15 years older.  While Essie Davis looks marvelous for her age, you simply can't hide the bits that start to go first--the neck, the crepe-y areas on the chest near the armpits, and the like. Worse, the stylish outfits from that era expose those very parts of the body.  It's hard to abandon all disbelief in the vampy Miss Fisher when she's *quite* a bit older than some of the lads she seduces, or because her charms are supposed to be irresistible. I mean, in the Mrs. Bradleys, nobody tried to pretend that Diana Rigg was vamping 30 year-olds, and while it's not quite exactly on target...it's close enough.  And this is a shame, too, because much of the rest of the series isn't too bad.The other character actors are all quite good--Bert and Cec are great; the indefatigable Dot is portrayed wonderfully. (She alone is worth watching). Her cop beau is played perfectly by a good young Australian actor.  Inspector Jack Robinson, who apparently is being set up as a love interest, is well-done, although quite a bit different than the Robinson from the novels.  The early problems that the series displayed with mediocre CQ (Computer Graphics) generated sets and backdrops seems to have mostly been fixed with the application of some money. ;-)But the stridency of the Phyrne character, as she boldly leads the way with men in tow...it's just a bit overdone.  Her decisiveness in the show comes off as being snotty and arrogant, and her vamping is sort of tawdry.  I'm certainly no prude; it's just that same little squirm that your stomach gives when you see a middle-aged woman at a wedding that's had one too many drinks start fawning over a guy in college.  You feel a bit sorry for her, and uncomfortable for him.  When I see youngish actors in the scene with Essie Davis, I get the same feeling, and as I said, that's really unfortunate, because otherwise, I think that this series could be really fun to watch.  As it's clearly too late to replace Essie Davis (who would have been the PERFECT Phryne Fisher 15 years back), they ought to consider toning some of the "everyone does what Phryne says because they all want to be with her" Mary Sue aspect, to make it a little less unbelievable; focus more on the mysteries and less on the "young adventurous hottie" part of the story.  The Phryne as-is could still be vampy, but her prey ought to be more age-appropriate for her, which would lend credibility.  Otherwise, it makes you wonder if the star of the show PAID to make the show, to speak bluntly--it's a bit surprising that none of the wardrobe or makeup or lighting people have noticed that her age is showing, and made appropriate changes to disguise it more.  (As best possible--we all know that the camera is a cruel mistress!).The mysteries themselves are cute; as stated, the other actors in the ensemble are really quite excellent; the costuming is strong, and the CQ is better than it was.  It's not a bad way to spend 50 minutes, but it could be better had it had slightly more suitable casting for the heroine's lead.  If you like the PF mysteries, you'll likely enjoy the TV show.
summary: Not for you if you're expecting Mrs. Bradley, but not awful.

reviewText: Fans of Mrs. Bradley, Tommy & Tuppence, Lord Peter Wimsey and other detective series set in the Jazz Age rejoice! reviewText: Every time another detective series comes out from Acorn Media it begs the question: “Can this be as good as—?” (Fill in the blank with “Midsomer Murders”, “Trial & Retribution”, “George Gently”, etc.) The short answer with MISS FISHER’S MURDER MYSTERIES is a resounding “YES!”While there are many points in common with any murder mystery–there is at least one murder, for starters – there are always going to be details that distinguish the stand outs of this genre. To begin with here, there is Essie Davis.Ms. Davis exudes sex appeal the way Greta Garbo did. And Jean Harlow. Actually, Essie Davis is a sort of hybrid of the two with Garbo’s mystery and aloofness combined with Harlow’s earthy sexiness. Though often refined, like Garbo, Davis is also unabashedly reckless at times, with a live-life-to-the-fullest joie de vivre that is immensely appealing, even when we lose count of how many lovers she has in the course of thirteen episodes. (Shocking!)The attention to period detail rivals “Poirot”, the cleverness of the scripts reminds of “Midsomer Murders” and the acting is as good as any of them.What is particularly noteworthy is the abundance of strong female characters. While in some hands this might come across as “making a statement”, here it is simply a natural progression of the premise. Miss Phryne (pronounced FRY-nee) Fisher is a woman of considerable wealth who has come up in the world from having nothing. She has suffered tragedy, been abused and seen and served in the Great War and is the stronger and wiser for it. Haunted by the unexplained loss of her younger sister years before, Phryne shows no bitterness. Rather, she masks her vulnerability with abundant generosity and acts of kindness. The way she refers to her personal maid, Dot, as her “companion” for example, erases all consciousness of the class system, which is so strongly evident in most period pieces.Dot is a delight, a stark contrast to her employer in terms of innocence and experience, yet she holds her own in a tight spot and frequently justifies Miss Fisher’s absolute trust in her. The relationship is not unlike Holmes and Watson in some ways and is a delight to behold as it develops throughout the first series.At the time of this writing, a second series is being filmed, so there is much more to look forward to in this beautifully-produced Australian program. And there is much to love about Miss Fisher, too, though when she tilts her head and gives you the eye, you’ll likely begin by being flat-out smitten.Here’s to a long and entertaining relationship.

reviewText: The Honorable Phryne Fisher doesn't care what you think; she will run wild, have romances, and investigate murders if she wants. She has the gumption other flapper-era women lack, and a keen eye for detail. She also doesn't mind crossing the infinitely forgiving Inspector Jack Robinson. What she lacks, though, is the ability to outrun the ghosts she wants to silence with her "lady detective" work.This Australian TV series, based on Kerry Greenwood's novels, harkens back to an earlier time in television history. This doesn't just mean its lush Jazz Age stylings and design. It also eschews rambling subplots, slow mounting exposition, and Hill Street Blues busyness. It has the kind of unadorned straight-arrow narrative and period stylings that keep audiences returning to Miss Marple and Upstairs, Downstairs.Phryne ("FRY-knee") Fisher was born poor in colonial Melbourne, served in the ambulance corps in World War I, and bounced around paris with Hemingway and Picasso. But with all the wartime deaths, a title skipped several cousins, and the poor colonial girl becomes a Lady. Now she's back in Melbourne as a freelance detective, mixing a little G'day into her CSI stew, in the waning days Roaring Twenties.Essie Davis, best known to world audiences for a supporting role in the Matrix sequels, plays Miss Fisher as a woman who has to keep her happy mask permanently fixed. Her smile seems stretched a little too wide, as though if she forgets for a minute, she'll start crying--and she does, at times. In ways, she seems the very emblem of the 1920s, cash-strapped but profligate, trying to dance wartime memories away.Nathan Page as Inspector Robinson wants to be her opposite number, all button-down suits and legal procedure. Page's high, knife-sharp cheekbones give Inspector Robinson a hungry look, and his unsmiling, puppy-eyed demeanor cracks occasionally, just enough to permit glimpses of his own damaged history. The story doesn't even pretend Miss Fisher and Jack Robinson won't eventually end up together. It respects us too much for that.Davis and Page, the billed stars, headline a remarkable cast combining relative unknowns with Australian stars. Miranda Otto, who played Eowyn in LotR, appears in the first episode, but she's probably the only star international audiences will recognize. This leaves us free to enjoy the characters as they are, unencumbered by prior expectations their respective CV's bring along.The set design and cinematography have a very retro look. Not just in their attempt to recreate Melbourne in 1928, but also in how the directors and designers work around limited resources. Careful re-dressing and camera angles allow the same cobblestone alley to represent several different streets. Rolling smoke and limited light allow small sets to look larger. When in doubt, reshoot the added footage from the opposite angle.Combining these Hitchcock-like techniques with spirited performances in which the actors tacitly acknowledge the cheesiness, the show manages the same wonder we remember from Dark Shadows or the original Doctor Who: being cheap without looking cheap. Even on those occasions when we can see sets wobble, the actors persevere with such cheeky aplomb that we can't help wanting to follow along.Australia remains, for Northern Hemisphere audiences, the other side of the world. Despite Reagan-era flirtation with Crocodile Dundee and "Do You Come From a Land Down Under," we remain unaware of the land; Australian actors like Hugo Weaving and Hayden Christensen leave the country and suppress their accents to find high-paying work. We just don't know much about the Antipodes.This series shows a side of Australia not much known to outsiders. The colonial situation gives the story a distinct texture: Australians have their own accent and culture, but still spend pounds and fly the Union Jack. Revolutionary Leninist sentiment abuts against Crumbling Empire gentility, shocking poverty against remarkable wealth. Miss Fisher, born poor and accidentally rich, repeatedly finds herself at the nexus.The murders almost don't matter. As in Sherlock Holmes or Hercule Poirot, the body exists to hook audiences into the protagonist's display of considerable acumen. But Miss Fisher and Inspector Robinson don't completely exclude Dashiell Hammett-esque grit; their investigations frequently take them down sooty alleys or expose the seamy underside of apparent colonial glamour.Miss Fisher's retinue seems like a cooling blast from the past, when detectives didn't need to cuss, and "good guys" still existed. This show has murder, but little blood; afterglow, but no graphic sex. It will speak to audiences who remember when TV reflected our aspirations, not our failures.

reviewText: "Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries" is a thirteen episode import from Australia that should appeal to anyone who enjoys the PBS "Mystery" series.  I say this for two reasons.  The network did introduce "Miss Fisher" to North American television, but (less concretely) this production just seems to embody everything that the "Mystery" brand encompasses.  If you watch the show, I'm certain you'll know what I mean.  This is a breezy look at 1920's Melbourne seen through the eyes of a truly rare breed, a lady detective named Phryne Fisher.  As played with pluck and charm by Essie Davis, it's almost impossible to dislike this interpretation of novelist Kerry Greenwood's heroine.  The show is absolutely beautiful to look at, rendered in exquisite period detail in staging and costuming.  It's just flirty and fun, if not particularly substantial.  This is, however, a very female-centric program.  Almost all of the major characters are women, men are sidelined altogether or are mere plot points to maneuver around in any given mystery.  The exception is Nathan Page (as a Detective Inspector) who is simply around as a skeptical foil for the intrepid investigator.Spread across four discs, the complete run time is just shy of twelve hours (each episode clocks in at about 55 minutes).  There are a few bonus features including a featurette about the show's look, a brief word with the creators, and a few cast interviews.  Although interesting enough if you're a fan, there's nothing particularly revelatory or deep about this added content.The episodes included are:(1) Cocaine Blues, (2) Murder on the Ballarat Train, (3) The Green Mill Murder, (4) Death at Victoria Dock, (5) Raisins and Almonds, (6) Ruddy Gore, (7) Murder in Montparnasse, (8) Away With The Fairies, (9) Queen of the Flowers, (10) Death by Miss Adventure, (11) Blood and Circuses, (12) Murder in the Dark, and (13) King Memses' Curse.There is no doubt that "Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries" caters primarily to a certain type of audience.  You'll know (probably just by looking at the packaging and title) fairly early on if you fall into that group.  In many ways, this is an extremely traditional mystery series.  The cases, which range in quality, will be wrapped satisfactorily by the end of the hour.  There are some continuing characters which pop up periodically but don't make much impact.  It isn't until the last few episodes where we get a story arc bigger and more personal than the other lightweight adventures that have preceded it and these were my favorites.Although I enjoyed "Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries"as a diversion, I'm not certain how memorable or distinctive it is.  The cases are fanciful and the plots routine.  But in the moment, Essie Davis has charisma to spare and I was happy to sit down with her for these episodes.  And as I said, this is absolutely gorgeous to look at.  When it returns for a Second Season, I'd love to see them push a bit further past the expected formula.  The show is good, but it has the potential to be great.  KGHarris, 3/13.

reviewText: "Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries" are based on historical mystery novels by Australian author Kerry Greenwood that feature the Honourable Phryne Fisher, a wealthy, adventurous, slightly bohemian woman who survived an impoverished childhood, working in an ambulance unit in France during the Great War, inheriting a fortune, and went on to set herself up as a lady private detective in her hometown of Melbourne, Australia, where she continues to live life to the fullest. I have not read the novels, so I cannot compare, but the television series is not so much "historical fiction" as a fantacist's conception of the 1920s. It's utterly cartoonish. It's a burlesque, from Miss Fisher's outrageous wardrobe to the anachronistic social mores and manners.If the writing has a place in time, it is firmly in the 21st century, not the 1920s. But, strangely, the series does not have a strong sense of place, which is disappointing. The Melbourne portrayed is a generic Anglo-Saxon culture. Half of the characters speak with English, not Australian, accents. Surely, Melbourne had some distinguishing characteristics. A clear sense of time and place would have gone a long way to elevating the series to more than something to watch if you have nothing else to do. On the other hand, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation wisely limited the episodes to 1 hour each. Plots have been simplified rather than complicated. Though that has downsides, it is better than the BBC's recent tendency to bloat mystery plots to 90 minutes.There is a regular cast of characters, Miss Fisher's friends and associates, who appear in multiple episodes. But it is Miss Fisher, herself, who scuttles the series' potential. Rather than an adventurous, irrepressible young woman, the Phryne Fisher of this series is an overbearing, smarmy, smug middle-aged woman. She's distasteful. Her dialogue, if you only read it on the page, gives the impression of a bubbly young woman who turns serious and clever when the circumstances call for it. But that dialogue is delivered totally wrong. The actress Essie Davis looks over 35 and is in fact over 40. A middle-aged woman cannot get away with anything just by batting her eyelashes, but Phryne does. She flirts with every man under 30 whom she meets. And they flirt back!I have no idea what the producers of this show were thinking when they cast someone so unsuitable in the title role. Were there no pretty young actresses who can play clever in Australia? Or England? And must Phryne be so conspicuously over-dressed for everything? And pursue an assailant across a slanted rooftop in high heels? Were they glued to her feet? Mercifully, the rest of the cast worked out better. Ashleigh Cummings is charming as Miss Fisher's maid and faithful companion Dot Williams. She seems entirely ingenuous, and her expressions are priceless. Hugo Johnstone-Burt is also terrific as Dot's slow and shy beau, police Constable Hugh Collins. And the handsome Nathan Page makes an appealing and tolerant Detective Inspector Jack Robinson.The plots are unremarkable and rely heavily on implausible co-incidences, though the series improves over time until the last two episodes. The writers have introduced a recurring subplot that does not appear in the novels: Miss Fisher is determined to ensure that the man convicted of murdering her younger sister when they were children will stay behind bars. She is pre-occupied with understanding her sister's fate. The last episode is not based on a book but rather was written to resolve this child abduction subplot. It's beyond terrible and barely watchable. The entire subplot is ill-advised and makes Phryne appear neurotic. Again, I can't imagine what the writers were thinking. It's not as if they needed more plot. Well, it's something to look at on a rainy day.
summary: Burlesque of 1920s, but Fun, Except for the Main Character.

reviewText: Ladies and gentlemen 'tis the season when there's nothing on the tube other than re-runs or (mostly) sub-par network dramas, so if you're like me then you're just plain bored! Let's face it, there are times when (GASP!) we don't feel like flipping through a book. We just want to flop down on the couch with the remote and a bowl of chips and binge on Netflix or burn through half of our DVD collections in a week.A few days ago, I hung out with my best friend and we started watching Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries. Needless to say, it turned into a three night event where we noshed on popcorn and cookies and watched telly for hours on end. It's probably not healthy to go through an entire season of a TV show in such a short time, but sometimes I think it's the only way to chill out and unwind. That's probably blasphemous coming from a book blogger but so be it, there's room here on this blog for more than one of my passions right? ;-)Anywho, back to Miss Fisher. Let's just say this isn't going to be a full on review of each episode of the series (this post would literally probably be a mile long) but rather the series as a whole. First and foremost -- it's fun! Phryne (pronounced Fry-nee) Fisher is a riot. When reading, sassy and full-of-life heroines are my favorite so naturally my favorite TV leads tend to exhibit the same characteristics. Phryne is the first to take the bull by the horns and dive into a case no matter how dangerous it promises to be. She is most definitely a thoroughly modern woman in every sense. She's definitely not shy when it comes to the opposite sex and has a series of dalliances. Did I mention her wardrobe is TO DIE FOR? Kudos to the costume designer for the stunning furs and gorgeous cloche hats. I kind of want to get in my time machine and travel back to the 1920s just for the fashion!The supporting characters are equally as entertaining and complex as Phryne. Oh my gosh, Detective Inspector Jack Robinson.... Straight-laced and all about solving the case, he's definitely a by the book kind of guy. When it comes to Miss Fisher, he's not as quick to warm up to her but when he does -- watch out! Sparks fly!Constable Hugh Collins, on the other hand is completely adorable with his boyish charm. Hugh is definitely a favorite of mine! Eager to please, he "tries" to do everything by the book but he's unable to say no to Phryne and especially not to Dot.Speaking of Dot, Miss Fisher's maid and companion (also a former suspect in Phryne's very first case), she balances out Phryne's intensity with her demureness and shy spirit. She does come out of her shell a bit but you'll see that of pretty much everyone who's a friend of Phryne's. Dr. Mac, Cec, Burt, Jane, and even Aunt Prudence are just a few more of the other characters who add flair and humor to an already splendid main cast of characters.If you're looking for something better than boring, old American TV I highly recommend this series. Just a word to the wise, you might not want to start watching the series late in the evening or you might just stay up well past your bedtime! Mystery, romance, and drama in spades make this a compulsively watchable show. I'm happy to say that series two is now in production and I for one can't wait to see it!~ My Rating: 5 out of 5 stars ~Love!*This review is from a series or movie I watched on my own time,a t my own expense. reviewText: Phryne (pronounced fry-nee) Fisher is an Australian Jazz Age Honey West, a free spirit, happily single at about 30, wealthy, sophisticated but down to earth, self-assured but with a more vulnerable, darker past, with the sexual attitudes of James Bond and the social attitudes (and commentaries) of the most modern liberal.Miss Fisher falls into her new avocation of lady private detective by chance but immediately proves a match for all comers with her gold-plated pistol, a little judo, and help from her trusty young maid/companion and small crew. reviewText: There is something undeniably charming about a murder mystery.  They don't involve accidental deaths or often even crimes of passion - a good murder mystery requires a clever plot, multiple suspects, and a fiendishly clever detective.  Invariably the sins that induce the murder - jealousy usually rearing its ugly head - are as intriguing as the murder  itself.  And there's something undeniably fun about mysteries that get wrapped up in tidy little bows - much more quaint than the sprawling messiness of life's real crimes."Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries" offers a spate of enjoyable little mysteries.  Our heroine is Phryne (pronounced "Fry-Nee") Fisher, a cosmopolitan aristocrat in 1920s Melbourne who is just rich enough, just smart enough, and definitely brave enough to spend her spare time tracking down murderers and foiling plots.  Phryne is a woman for the Roaring Twenties - she carries a gun, and when she's confronted with an illicit stash of cocaine, she tastes it for confirmmation . . . twice.  Played by the gorgeous Essie Davis, Phryne has all the moxie needed to track down the murderers of Melbourne."MFMM" is full of delightful little characters that one might expect in a BBC series.  Nathan Page does great work as Detective Jack Robinson and he leads a great ensemble cast that captures the innocence of the 1920s so darn easily.  In contrast to our jaded, cynical age, it's easy to believe these characters getting caught up in such colossal issues as whether a Catholic can date a Protestant.This is a tough series to review - it apparently has for its entire budget the amount that "Game of Thrones" spends on catering.  The footage is somewhat grainy, the action sequences are realistically poor, and it's clear that most of the scenes didn't get a second take.  (You can almost see the fog machines at work.)  Don't expect anything as glossy as "Dexter" or "True Blood" here.  But if you can get past that, you'll find a series of heart and brains, and isn't that what we're looking for in our stories?Highly recommended.

reviewText: I expected when I got this that I'd be watching it alone. Generally my husband and I will start a series together, but occasionally one of us decides it's just not our cup of tea. It sounded like Murder She Wrote set in the 1920s featuring an archly modern and clever flapper type female detective with great costumes. In fact, that's exactly what it was, which wouldn't have interested my husband at all except that's not all it was.Miss Fisher as a lead character delighted me. I rejoiced in the crow's feet around her eyes and her frank sensuality and unapologetic decadence. She seemed supremely self-satisfied, but still very caring and very ladylike. She seemed strong to me, very rarely reaching for someone to help her, instead trying to help other people. A self-confident, well-educated lady who will live by her ethics but not any rules she doesn't set for herself. While it may seem a bit unrealistic, there are plenty of male characters drawn that way that people really do like. Well, I liked Miss Fisher.The supporting characters were just as wonderful. My husband really liked Burt and Cec and their interaction with each other. The kind of friendship that can speak volumes in just a look was well portrayed and recognizable. Mr. Butler was resourceful and strong. Dot, in her sweetness and innocence seems to be growing into a character with uncompromising principles based in kindness and loyalty. Jack Robinson wasn't nearly as interesting to me personally as the rest of the characters.The costumes are amazing and wonderful. After the first episode, I decided if I hated the show, it could be viewed with the sound muted just to see the costumes. Every feather, fringe and bead was just glorious. The shawls and wraps, and the way Miss Fisher wore them will make a lot of women decide that a shawl is the most necessary fashion accessory they can own.In fact, I enjoyed the show almost completely. It was charming. The only episode I didn't like was the last one in the set which didn't fit the mood of the earlier episodes. That said, the wrap Miss Fisher wore at the end of it made up for the whole episode. I froze the scene and made some quick sketches because it's something that I want to make for myself. If the show worked for me just on the level as a seamstress and as light entertainment, it also still worked for my husband who is not as interested in costumes.
summary: Lovely costumes, engaging characters, very enjoyable

Next thing we know, she's out on the town in flapper attire and  manhunter mode  digging up dirt and doing the tango with the most gorgeous guy in the room.  Next day, it's  back to the crime scene where she announces her new choice of career: Detective.  By which time the tolerance level of the Melbourne police detectives on the case, as well  as that of this viewer, was wearing very thin.Had I not found myself  with four DVD discs' worth of season one episodes, I'd have called it quits at the end of episode one.  But  I felt obligated to plow on, for awhile at least.  Somewhere around the third or fourth episode, I had to admit that the shows were cleverly plotted, exceptionally well filmed and full of  Roaring Twenties atmosphere. reviewText: Obviously, I'm late to the "party" in discovering this delightful "mystery" series from the Australian Broadcasting Company (yes, another ABC!). There are already 115 (!) reviews posted here so a lot of folks have obviously discovered it before I did! I'll try not to repeat what others have written but give you my own take on it, hoping that it might find an even wider audience.I discovered the DVD because it's being distributed in the US by Acorn Video - through whom I've discovered such great BBC series as "New Tricks" (still one of my Top Ten series). As a music journalist who loves 1920s jazz, I was drawn in by the "jazz age theme". The 1920s in Australia seemed to copy fashion from the "jazz Age" in the US, with the big difference being that there was no Prohibition in Australia.Most folks who gave this series less than five stars concentrated on the "mystery" aspect of the show. They said they were often easy to solve. Honestly, I didn't care if they did. The characters and the sets and the interaction between the recurring characters are what kept my attention (which is why I - and my folks - can enjoy performances of Sherlock Holmes stories, even if it's "The Hound of the Baskervilles" again! Phryne Fisher is one sexy lady and, when she is on the screen, you are immediately drawn to her - her face, her figure, and her clothes. And the sets are great.Then there is the music. During each episode at least one classic 1920s jazz record (and not the common ones) is played somewhere during the show and always over the end credits. Anyone who loves HBO's "Boardwalk Empire" for its "period music" will be hooked on this series too. It's not as violent though.I'll leave you to fellow reviewer Byron Kolln to give you an episode by episode summary but I would urge you to read it AFTER you've seen this series. There are way too many spoilers in many of the reviews, including Byron's, and this is a series which will charm you more the less you know.There's about 40 minutes of "bonus material" on the last disc, including the "making of, the sets, the creators and "meet the cast". Not essential but significant to add to the enjoyment.I understand that Season 2 is certain and I'll certainly be looking for that.I hope you found this review both informative and helpful.Steve Ramm"Anything Phonographic"
summary: Who cares about the "mystery" being solved when the heroine is so sexy and the 1920s music is so captivating.

What is more difficult to get used to if you are used to the tamer "cozy" mysteries of Agatha Christie and Ngaio Marsh (another Oceanian) is that there is a lot more explicit violence with blood and wounds, but it is still low key by today's standards.  Also, Miss Fisher "gets her man" in another way besides capturing the criminal in every episode so far.  I think there was an illusion to early methods of birth control in one episode, which explains why she does this without any obvious fear of pregnancy.  It was quick and I didn't rewind to be sure. reviewText: "Miss Fisher's Muder Mysteries Set 1", based on the books by Deb Cox and Fiona Eagger, revolves around the personal and professional life of Phryne Fisher, a glamorous private detective in 1920's Melbourne. The seemingly fearless socialite and heiress Phryne Fisher (Essie Davis, "Australia", "The Girl With A Pearl Earring", "Matrix: Reloaded) sashays around solving different murders and confronting mayhem. Unlike heroines of a similar background, Miss Fisher is a completely modern woman. She has a healthy libido and does not hesitate taking any man who catches her eye to bed; she also has a taste for alcohol, cocaine, and hash brownies.We meet her as she moves back to Sydney, Australia. As the series evolves, we learn that she served as a nurse during the war before settling in Paris when her ambulance group disbanded. Although she grew up in relative poverty, because of extensive casualties within her family during the war, she inherits enough money to enjoy a life of leisure.Her investigating career begins by accident during lunch at an old friend's house; she arrives to find her friend's husband has been murdered. In the process of uncovering the culprit, she has time for a fling with an expatriate Russian dancer and to expose an illegal abortion ring and a drug kingpin. Flushed with her success she decides to go into business as a private detective.She takes on one of the maids from the household of the murder victim as a lady's companion. Dorothy "Dot" Williams (Ashleigh Cummings) is a rather naive and sheltered young woman who has had a very strict Catholic upbringing. She is also slightly in awe of her employer's freedom and over the course of the series, we watch as Dot loses some of her naivety and discovers her own strengths and courage.The other two main characters are members of Sydney's finest; Inspector Jack Robinson (Nathan Page) and Constable Hugh Collins (Hugo Johnstone-Burt). Initially Robinson treats Miss Fisher as one might expect from an experienced police officer of the 20s confronted with what he considers a socialite out looking for thrills. However, he soon grows to respect and admire her, both for her skills as a detective and as a person.This series is special because of the acting and the relationships between the characters. The two leads have a wonderful chemistry reminiscent of some of great screen couples of the past. Although Miss Fisher has a rotating series of lovers, her relationship with Inspector Robinson gradually evolves into something more than just colleagues and friends. However, both of them are hesitant about making any sort of commitment because of events in their past. It is obvious they have reached a point where they have to make a decision about the direction their relationship, but what that will be is still in up in the air."Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries" is a well scripted and directed set of 13 murder mysteries on four DVDs, but what makes it a joy to watch are the performances of the lead actors, especially Davis. She is beguiling and a pleasure to watch. If you have ever seen a Poirot or a Marple on PBS, this series gets the attention to detail just as right, making the period of time come alive. But the real difference is in the portrayal of the lead; this is a very modern woman, ready and willing to try anything and to get her hands dirty. Not only does she play the flighty socialite to perfection, but she has the ability to allow us to see beneath her devil may care exterior to show the vulnerable and sensitive person beneath. It's not often we are treated to such a strong multi-dimensional female character in the lead role of a television series played by an actor more than equal to the task.

reviewText: Based on the Kerry Greenwood novels, Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries is set during the Jazz Age (1928 Melbourne, to be exact). Phryne (pronounced Fry-knee) Fisher (played superbly by Australian film star Essie Davis) has returned to Australia after some years abroad. Almost immediately, she sets foot in a mystery involving opium smuggling. Having a keen awareness and wit, she steps in with an offer of help, only to find her services are not wanted. Not deterred in the least, Phryne sets off with her gold and pearl-handled Smith and Wesson and involves herself in solving the murder and discovers her calling, to be a lady detective. Twelve further episodes detail her adventures and show a growing skill in solving crime, even to the consternation of Detective Inspector Jack Robinson. Others have summarized all thirteen episodes and the special on the filming and cast. I have only seen five episodes, but I must say each one is outstanding. The sets recreate the time period beautifully, and the costumes, especially Miss Davis', are gorgeous. The period cars are wonderful, especially Phryne's Hispano-Suiza. The cast of characters is brilliant. Nathan Page plays Detective Jack Robinson, Miriam Margoyles plays Aunt Prudence. Ashleigh Cummings is Dot, Phryne's very timid and very Catholic assistant.At this point, we know Phryne had a sister Jane, who met a tragic end, and the man responsible is behind bars. More of her life will be revealed in further episodes, but I would say that each one I've seen is splendid and they just get better as we develop a vested interest in the characters.There's a little coarse language, drugs and sex, but it's all done with a light hand and most people would not find it offensive. Phryne is a woman of the world and behaves accordingly.I love this series and can highly recommend it. It's both witty and elegant (and not just for the costumes).I have now watched ten episodes. Last night's offering was titled Death by Miss Adventure and deals with the suspicious death of a young female factory worker. Phryne sends her assistant Dot to work undercover at the factory to see what she can discover. This episode's topics include illicit love and lesbianism, each handled with the sensitivity of the time period. I especially enjoyed some of the small but realistic details such as the lockers where the factory girls stored their belongings and the starkness of a hospital room in the twenties. Very well done.Update: I have watched all episodes plus the specials section with cast interviews, scenes around Melbourne, costuming and sets, vintage autos and trains. I still feel this production was/is first class and I'm delighted that a second season is underway. The ending wasn't quite what I had expected but was appropriate to the series and leaves room for further speculation. Two thumbs way up for Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries.

reviewText: When I first sat down to watch the first episode of MISS FISHER'S MURDER MYSTERIES, SEASON 1, ("Cocaine Blues") I didn't think I would like it. Overall, I enjoy murder mysteries, but the idea of a murder mystery show revolving around a 1928 rich and single female sleuth from Australia didn't sound very appealing to me. I couldn't have been more wrong.Based upon the books and stories by Kerry Greenwood, MISS FISHER'S MURDER MYSTERIES follows the adventures (and sometimes misadventures) of Miss Phryne Fisher (portrayed by Essie Davis) a wealthy, independent, and glamorous socialite. The series begins when Miss Fisher returns to her hometown of Melbourne, Australia after living overseas for several years. Through the course of the series, we learn that in addition to living the high life with some very wealthy suitors, Phryne spent some time as an artist's model in Paris and as a nurse during the Great War.Phyrne is highly intelligent and well educated. She drives a car, can fly a plane, sometimes wears pants, and carries a pearl-handled pistol in her purse (or on her body).Phyrne has a strong charisma that attracts not only several male suitors, but a menagerie of close friends including her devout Catholic maid Dot Williams (Ashleigh Cummings); police Detective Inspector John "Jack" Robinson (Nathan Page); Inspector Robinson's second-in-command and Dot's love interest, Constable Hugh Collins (Hugo Johnstone-Burt); household manager and Miss Fisher's butler, Mr. Butler (Richard Bligh); taxi drivers and best friends, Bert (Travis McMahon) and Cec (Anthony Sharpe); and Phyrne's society matron Aunt Prudence (Miriam Margolyes). Along the way, Phyrne also takes in a foster child, Jane (Ruby Rees-Wemyss) who becomes her ward.The basic plot of each episode usually follows the usual format of a murder mystery: there's a brief prologue that sets the scene and shows the victim either being murdered or being discovered. However, taking a note from Agatha Christie, sometimes the cases aren't as easy to figure out and there are strange twists that are thrown in. The cases that Phyrne involves herself with are as interesting as the different people in her life. Opium drug rings, abortion doctors, child slavery operations, bigamy, interracial marriage, terrorism, homosexuality, true hermaphroditism, child predators, and mental illness are just some of the issues that Phyrne deals with when solving crimes. Also, there is a sub-story that courses through several episodes in the series that isn't resolved until the final climatic episode of the season. As a child, Phryne's younger sister Janey was kidnapped and presumably murdered by a university professor named Murdoch Foyle (Nicholas Bell). Though Foyle was charged for the abduction of several children, the body of Janey was never discovered. Foyle never confessed to actually killing her and the lack of closure from that case is the one thing that unsettles Phyrne to her core.There are thirteen episodes in the series. In addition, the last disc in the collection contains several special features about the show, including a short interview with Phyrne's creator, Kerry Greenwood.I really enjoyed MISS FISHER'S MURDER MYSTERIES. I found the show highly entertaining. The characters are interesting and fun to watch. Most of the episodes stand alone and can be watched by themselves (except episodes 11-13), but the overarching subplot that ties the whole series together makes the show even that much more intriguing. I was also really impressed with the show's production values. Everything about the period has been recreated in great detail, from the buttons on clothing down to the decals on cars. Recreating an era from the past on screen is not an easy task, but specifically recreating 1928 Melbourne, Australia is even more difficult and the series' production staff did an amazing job of doing so.Overall, MISS FISHER'S MURDER MYSTERIES is a highly enjoyable mystery series that has some great acting and super production values. It's a series that I think even those who don't enjoy murder mysteries might actually like watching (at least a few episodes). Now that I've seen the show, I can't wait to get the books and read them.
summary: I Haven't Enjoyed a Murder Mystery Show This Much Since MONK

reviewText: We went into this series of DVDs blind, having never seen the show... but it sounded fun, and for the most part it has lived up to or exceeded expectations and I would recommend it to most anyone.While not as extravagantly produced as a big budget American series, or a prestige British series, like Downton Abbey, they have nonetheless done a wonderful job of recreating the world of 1920's Australia. The program is full of slightly (not overly) eccentric characters and has a delightful light touch. Miss Fisher herself is a refreshingly modern and humorous woman trying to balance her socialite world with that of a practicing detective.If you've never seen the show before, I encourage you to give it a whirl.

reviewText: I've always been fascinated by the flapper era, with its liberated jazz babies who were witty, elegant, and more often than not a match for any man. In Miss Phryne Fisher, complete with her Louise Brooks bob, we have all of that & more, as she proves herself a worthy detective in the darker sections of 1920s Australia. No shrinking violet either professionally or in her personal life, she eagerly embraces all that the era has to offer as she solves crimes that might daunt more than one male colleague. And as with the best fictional detectives, both Phryne & her world are enhanced by a stellar collection of secondary characters, each with personalities that provide contrasts & counterpoints to her own. There's only so much you can do with basic crime plots at this point, as they've all been done many times before, so a compelling lead & a background that oozes atmosphere are both essential to maintain interest. This collection is full to the brim! What makes Phryne especially watchable is the contrast between her glittering, sophisticated, carefree surface & the dreadful horror of her past, which drives her despite the occasional upwelling of fear -- because she's not always quite as self-confident as she'd like the world to think. This is the sort of series where you'll revel over the period detail & amused asides just as much as the mysteries themselves -- highly recommended!
summary: Dark alleys, decadence, and an amateur detective more than ready for both
